intro: Monotropastrum humile var. glaberrimum, commonly known as the glabrous mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while producing its own carbohydrates through photosynthesis using the light it captures. The plant has small, scale-like leaves and produces white or pale green berries that are often eaten by birds. It is typically found in forested areas of eastern North America, where it thrives on a variety of host trees. Its unique ecological role contributes to the biodiversity of its habitat by supporting bird populations and influencing forest dynamics.
